title: About
text: This blog is mainly for my Mom, so she can stay up to date as I travel by bike from Sweden to Italy.

title: Welcome
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Test Me
text: About this blog

title: Haida Gwaii
text: A successful shakedown cruise to Haida Gwaii - Literally the hurricane force winds blew me over.

title: Packing for Europe
text:
Did a “dry fit” and the bike feels manageable and looks cute.
I packed slightly less gear than what I took to Haida Gwaii in April and its noticeably lighter and more balanced.

Got a cardboard bike box and wine box and stuffed them both to the brim. I hope to ditch the warm extra clothing as the trip progresses.
The final packing list includes:

Bike 2013 Trek 520 (updated cassette, handlebars, saddle, pedals). A beautiful burly steel frame with 700c tires
Front and rear bike lights
Spare tubes
Zap straps
Electrical tape
Spare nuts and bolts
Spare chain links
Pedal wrench
Handlebar spacers
Tire levers
Wet and dry chain lube Chain / bike cleaning rag
Mini tire pump
Leatherman
Small camp pot
Bowl/plate combo
Cutting board
Knife
Cutlery
Coffee mug (250 ml)
Lighter
Camp suds
Pour over coffee maker (splurge)
No stove because it was confiscated by air Canada when flying to Haida Gwaii. A new fancy one will be purchased on Stockholm.
3 shirts 1 pair of shorts 2 pairs of pants
Sleeping pants
Many pairs of undies
3 sporty bras
4 pairs of socks
Swimsuit Puffy down jacket
Sweater Rain jacket
Rain pants
Medium weight waterproof bike gloves
Buff Toque
Ball cap
Sandals
Runners Bike cleats
2.5 litre bladder
500ml collapsible water bottle
5 ski straps
Solar light/battery bank
Block charger and cables
Point and shoot camera
Headlamp and extra bats
Bike bell Towel
Sunglasses Clear glasses
Helmet Medical kit
Cosmetics
Tent
Sleeping mat
Sleeping bag
Passport
Phone
Europe lonely planet book
Bags and panniers

title: About My Bike
text: My bike is a 2013 Trek 520 (updated cassette, handlebars, saddle, pedals). A beautiful burly steel frame with 700c tires

title: Flight to Sweden
text:
There was a medical emergency on the flight. The captain called for a doctor on the intercom multiple times but there weren’t any on the flight. An elderly woman appeared to be having a stroke or seizure. The EMTs took her from the plane at London Heathrow.
I didn’t pay attention to airport signage and cleared customs into the UK instead of heading to my gate. I showed my ticket to a helpful customs official and asked what to do and they said I’d have to go back through security at Terminal 5 by taking the lift to the train. And run because you don’t have any time. I got to security at Terminal 5 and was promptly asked to go to Terminal 2. I cleared security another sprint, lift, and train later and made it to my gate with minutes to spare.
Nicole’s flight landed before mine and we met at the hotel in Arlanda.

title: Rode to Stockholm
text: We woke to sunny skies and rode to Stockholm. Bike paths the entire way. We dropped our bags off at the Red Boat hotel and then walked Gamla Stan, seeing the Nobel Prize museum, royal palace, which has the most rooms out of any royal residence in Europe, parliament, etc.

title: Swedish Churches, Vikings and Meatballs
text: I toured one of the oldest churches in Sweden, so the sign read, before breakfast and heading out. We biked to Anundshög, a 500-900 ACE Viking archaeological site. It is Sweden’s largest burial mound and includes tumuli, a mound of earth raised over a grave (a Viking ship in this case) and stone ships. The ships outline what would have been large ships used as tombs for Viking kings. We rode to Arboga with another strong head wind to Arboga and had Swedish meatballs for dinner.

title: Örebro to Hallsberg
text: We contemplated catching a train to Gothenburg as the highway riding hadn’t been the nicest or what we expected. Instead, we drank a bunch of coffee and biked towards Örebro. I toured the castle, a palimpsest built between 1300-1600, used mostly as a prison and torcher chamber. It was creepy. Nicole opted out, sat in the sun and had a coffee and pastry. We ate lunch at Dirty Taco and I almost had a run in with peanuts. Peanuts on tacos? Another strong headwind until Hallsberg. Burgers, beer, and premier league before bed.

title: Laundry in Kungälv
text: We had a relaxing day with Pia and Mats in Kungälv and ate them out of house and home. We did laundry and now have clean undies and socks.

title: Grästorp to Kungälv
text: Biked from Grästorp to Kungälv. We cycled through another park and table mountain Kungajaktmuseet. A longer day than we had expected and ended with a strong headwind. I felt like I was going to be blown off my bike for a few hours but Nicole coached me through it. Ended the day with Pia and Mats, two unbelievably gracious hosts in Kungälv. We had a delicious dinner and went to bed early.

title: On to the New EuroVelo
text: Lox for breakfast and the tastiest I have ever had! Most interesting biking day and we have linked onto a EuroVelo route that is under development. Met a 77 year old man who had a new looking bike that he had ridden over 30,000km on. Biked through the UNESCO Platabergens geo park. Exceptionally beautiful sedimentary formations backed by lake Vanern.

title: Swedish Churches, Vikings and Meatballs
text: I toured one of the oldest churches in Sweden, so the sign read, before breakfast and heading out. We biked to Anundshög, a 500-900 ACE Viking archaeological site. It is Sweden’s largest burial mound and includes tumuli, a mound of earth raised over a grave (a Viking ship in this case) and stone ships. The ships outline what would have been large ships used as tombs for Viking kings. We rode to Arboga with another strong head wind to Arboga and had Swedish meatballs for dinner.

title: Marstrand and Gothenburg
text: Pia and Mats took us to Marstrand, a small island near Kungälv, north of Gothenburg. According to the informational signage, Marstrand became a playground for the rich and famous after King Oscar II visited and built his summer home. It’s beautiful. We reluctantly left Pia and Mats after our island tour and after they gave us parting gifts - cheese cutters, which are fantastic and which we will put to use! We rode through Gothenburg and found a campsite.

title: Hallsberg to Maiestad
text: Another sunny day! We forgot it was Sunday and had a challenging time finding food. We slept on a picnic table outside a coop that had the largest packages of wasa crackers I have ever seen. Biked to Mariestad on Lake Vanern in that strong, westerly headwind. It looks like cottage country. More premier league before a lot of stretching and bed.

title: Toodling Around the Coast
text: Woke from camping in Askim and toodled along the coast. Beautiful and relaxing riding until we got our first flat! Nic changed her tire while I ate cake and drank coffee. The Swedish have this lovely tradition called “fika”, a coffee and/or cake break. We are strong proponents and often fika more than once per day.

title: More on Copenhagen
text:
We toured the NY Carlsberg Glyptotek. Very cool museum with Danish painters, Roman sculpture, and a large ancient Egyptian exhibition. Lots of colonialism and lots of exceptional preservation work.
I toured the Danish Architecture Centre. It has a dedicated area to one of my favourite urbanists, Jan Gehl. He systematized a way to make a bomber city even better and you can feel it in the streets.
We met up with Signe, a friend of a friend, for dinner and learned some interesting Copenhagen facts. The little mermaid was on loan in China for a period and thousands of folks have photos with a fake mermaid.

title: Last Day in Sweden
text: Our last day in Sweden! Beautiful 90km day along a coastal bike path from Bastad to Grevie. We hiked up to Helsingborg castle and took the ferry to Helsingor. We toured the Kronborg castle, which Shakespeare based Hamlet, and watched people beaching and fishing on the grounds.

title: Mini Golf!
text: Easy 80km day without any wind! Nicole had a nice nap on the bank of the Nissan River after we downed some warm and disgusting snaps. We stopped for mini golf, which Nicole won, and had pizza. Nice camping north of Bastad.

title: Made it to Copenhagen, Denmark
text: We hit 1000km today and made it to Copenhagen! The cycling is something to get used to. Yes, the infrastructure is fantastic for cyclists. Yes, cars and locals move very quickly and aren’t all that happy about panniers. We toured Free Town Christiania, a really interesting with a flat governance structure and its highest authority being the community meeting. It’s also where to buy weed in Copenhagen. I’m not sure why I assumed weed was legal in Denmark but it’s not! Fee town: https://www.christiania.org/info/pages-in-english/

title: More on Copenhagen
text:
We toured the NY Carlsberg Glyptotek. Very cool museum with Danish painters, Roman sculpture, and a large ancient Egyptian exhibition. Lots of colonialism and lots of exceptional preservation work.
I toured the Danish Architecture Centre. It has a dedicated area to one of my favourite urbanists, Jan Gehl. He systematized a way to make a bomber city even better and you can feel it in the streets.
We met up with Signe, a friend of a friend, for dinner and learned some interesting Copenhagen facts. The little mermaid was on loan in China for a period and thousands of folks have photos with a fake mermaid.

title: 1000m Decent!!!
text:
A scenic bike to Mistretta, followed by a 940m decent, (zero pedalling!), through olive groves and flowers to the ocean. It was an easy peasy cycle along the water to a nice camping space on the beach
Around 4pm I biked back to a grocery store and it started to rain. Luckily I had my rain gear! The locals thought I was an alien cycling in the rain and many waved me into their sheltered spaces.

title: Night in Nicosia
text:
I decided to follow a route from a Sicilian cycle guiding company. At the time, I didn’t realize that it was marketed towards mountain e-bikes. I followed SP83 around the north side of the lake. Sicilian roads, maybe Italian roads in general, are decided into three major classes outside of the municipal road system. “E” are major highways and bikes are not permitted, “SS” are state highways and generally well maintained, “SP” are provincial roads maintained by the provinces and local authorities. SP roads can transition from a narrow asphalt path to sand, coarse 2” gravels, etc. They also don’t appear to have any civil engineering requirements for road gradient. All this is to say that the SP route was scenic but also the most physically challenging 3 hours I have experienced.
I stayed in near Nicosia, another stunning hill town. Tall cliffs are dotted with caves, which were home to many until the 1950s.
Caves that people lived in within those rocky mounds.

title: Fraud in Denmark!!!
text: Rode from Niel’s place along mostly gravel roads to Soby to catch the Ferry from Aero to Als. The route took us past many thatched manor houses with small farms. Almost everything is digital in Denmark, including ferry tickets and bookings. We couldn’t book using the app and asked the local harbour master for help. The ordeal resulted in Nicole’s credit card being flagged for fraud and us walking aboard without paying. We decided to have a short ride after a few flats. Nicole spent first bit of the evening changing tubes and tires around and the second bit tasting beers at the local brewery.

title: Last day with Nicole
text: Met Emma, Nicole’s exchange student, at her house for breakfast. What a spread! Emma and her boyfriend, Fabian, toured us around her beighbourhood biked with us to the train station. Our train was late and we missed our connection but go into Frankfurt with time to pack up Nicole’s bike with cardboard from the recycling bin and have beers. Our last day of cycling together.

title: Off to Italy Solo!
text:
Woke up at 2am to load my bike and cycled 12km to the airport. I was the only person, (one rabbit), on the signed bike path to terminal 1. Purchased a bike box and a roll of tape for €25 at luggage services and loaded the box to the brim. The kind folks at Lufthansa baggage check coached me into saying that the box was 23kg, which is under the maximum of 25kg for this airline. It was definitely over the maximum weight and they knew it! The airport and security were empty and I got through security at 4:45am - a comfortable 3 hours early.
Called Alex in the airport. He has lettuce and potentially kale and spinach growing at home!
Arrived in Catania, Sicily, and biked to The Yard Hostel. Toured the streets, street market, monastery turned liberal / arts university, and cathedrals.

title: Ærøskøbing and an Organic Farm
text: Took the ferry from Svendborg to Ærøskøbing. We met a lovely local at the ferry terminal who happened to be a cycling enthusiast with a collection of 15 bikes. She gave us the local cycling scoop. Ærø was by far the best cycling of the trip with heaps of cycling dedicated infrastructure and businesses. We popped into Ærø Bryggeri, the local craft brewery, and met Nils, who was the previous director of the brewery and cigar shop. He was so kind and offered us a place to stay in one of the guest houses in his oceanfront farm. We stayed with two lovely young women from Hamburg and toured Nils organic farm and reestablished grassland.

title: Nicole’s Departure
text:
Nicole left for the airport around 6am. We were barely able to fit the packed bicycle box in the elevator. Our collective adventure has ended after almost 4 weeks and 1600km of dilly dallying.
An impressive 3 hours spent at the complimentary breakfast that included a spread of almost every breakfast food you can imagine. I also scored a sandwich for lunch and more instant coffee packets. I now have a collection of 17 instant coffee packets and will write a review on the best brand and roast once the scoring rubric is developed.
Biked to the airport to inquire about bike boxes. The Luggage Service employees are delightful! The said they’d have a box for me ready at 3am. I said that they made my day and one attendant responded saying that I made his as well by being kind.
Hopped onto the bike path from the airport to my hotel, a direct and signed path, and was instantly being honked at and yelled at in German by a line of 6 or 7 cars. Perhaps I have watched too many WW2 movies but being yelled at in German is disconcerting. Turns out that they were trying to let me know I dropped my sweater. Thanks to all who took the time to honk and yell!

title: With Friends in Germany
text: German trains are an absolute dream! Real humans at the ticket booth and no stairs to board in the bike compartment. Took the train from Rendsburg to Hamburg. We visited Speicherstadt and the adjacent Kontorhaus district - UNESCO designated warehouse districts along the Elbe. We hopped back on the train to Bremen, where we met up with Johanna, a friend of Nicole’s who took us stinky travellers in and made us delicious pizza. We stayed up until 1am - a personal best for the trip!

title: From Faxe to Odense
text:
We rode from Faxe, where the famous Faxe Kondi soda is from, and caught the train in Odense. We toured Egeskov Castle and it’s many gardens. It would be a cute date spot with a picnic.
A team of contractors was replacing a thatched roof. Those roofs are my favourite thing about Denmark! They use a scathe-looking tool to trim the straw!

title: Nordic-Norman and Byzantine cathedral
text: Toured the Nordic-Norman and Byzantine cathedral in Cefalu, another UNESCO World Heritage Site. Yes, that is correct by the way. The architecture is influenced by the French and English but was drafted and designed by Byzantine architects. So cool. Followed that tour by an unexpected beer fest along the beach, featuring many gluten free beers that were surprisingly delicious!

title: Highest Point in Denmark
text: We woke and went to the lime mine with Mille to search for fossils. Nicole has the focus and I fairy forgot it! After we went to the Forest Tower, which is almost the highest point in Denmark. It’s very cool. https://www.campadventure.dk/en/skovtaarnet/

title: Last day in Denmark
text:
We camped in Madeskov for free, including hot showers, because we were the first Canadians to stay at the site. We ferried from Sonderborg Denmark to Rendsburg, Germany. Food is much less expensive in Germany!
Flelensburg harbour is filled with wooden sailboats and boasts a rum museum. The town was made rich by the sugar and slave trade.

title: Coastal Riding in Denmark
text:
Signe recommended three bakeries and we naturally tried all three in one morning. We rode out of Copenhagen and met up with a cycle touring couple, Marie and Jean Paul. They plan a trip each year and had ridden from Brittany.
The coastal riding in Denmark is beautiful. We stopped at Stevns Klint, where a meteor hit earth and killed dinosaurs. It’s a UNESCO site and a fantastic stop. We then made our way to Faxe and met Kenn and Mille, A friend’s cousins. Kenn took us to an old water mill and windmill and the local lime mine.

title: UNESCO site in Bremen
text:
Johanna prepared us a delicious and decadent breakfast then took us on a tour of Bremen. As an excellent host, she managed to take us to all of the UNESCO sites. Personally, if I see a UNESCO site I am a very happy traveller. The Town Hall and the statue of Roland on the marketplace are representations of civic autonomy and sovereignty dating to the 1400s. Cool cool cool.
Johanna also took us out for spaghetti ice. I was skeptical about it and still find it strange after trying it.

title: Bremen to Neinburg
text: Fantastic riding from Bremen to Neinburg along quiet roads and MUPs. We spent hours at local restaurant drinking beer (Nicole) and fruity cocktails (Sarah). When we arrived at the campground it was gated and didn’t look open for the season. Turns out it was a Children’s summer camp but the nice owner let us camp and use the facilities. We had the beautiful property, zip line, go carts, etc. to ourselves. We picnicked on the lawn and did the Nicole booty buster workout, complete with deadlifts.

title: Nienburg to Garbsen
text: Another exceptional day of chill riding from Nienburg to Garbsen. We had our first swim of the trip in Steinhuder Meer and picnicked while watching the kite boarders and sailers.

title: The Hills of Sicily
text:
Took the wrong way out of Catania and started climbing Etna up to 1100m. Hung a left towards my route. I wanted to see some of the Sicilian hill towns, as they are described as some of the most beautiful in Italy. I didn’t take the climbing into account and ended up staying 15km from my planned campsite at La Dolce Vita b&b on Lago Pazzillo.
Stopped in Regalbuto on the way, the most beautiful town I have seen so far. There were older men walking lengths arm in arm in the main square. Two stopped me, shook my hand, and called me a lion! It was just what I needed after a challenging day riding. Then I went to a store for food and the grocery store was closed. Another pair of old men walked over to me and said “sandwich”? I nodded and they escorted me down the very centre of the road to an open “bar”. Turns out it was a bakery. Got two huge pizza bun things and 3 cookies.
